BARNSTORMER TICKETS
ON SALE AT LEVERING
Tickets for the "Black
Flamingo" are now on sale at
Levering Hall and also at Albaugh's Ticket Agency,8 East
Lexington Street.
The price of admission
ranges from 50 cents to $2.50.
Orchestra seats will be $2.00,
and $1.50. Possession of a
student activities card entitles
the holder to one $2.00 orchestra seat.
The Barnstormer's Dance
will take place each night after
the play, December 5th and
6th, at the Knights of Pythias
Hall. The price of admission
will be $1.00, even for those
holding reserved seat stubs.

At their meeting yesterday afternoon, the Interfraternity Board
failed to come to a definite decision
regarding rushing rules for the
coining year. However, it was decided that pledging would take
Place on the first or second Monday
of the second semester. If it occurs
011 the second Monday, the "Allotted Open House System" will be
;operative.
Under this plan each fraternity is
assigned one night when" it may
hold open house, on which -night it
-has priority over all others. The
Obvious benefit of such _a system is
to give the potential pledgee a
chance to attend all the open houses
he desires and orientate himself to
the best advantage.

LAYS GRAFT TO
PUBLIC APATHY

DR. W. H. SMITH CITES
NEEDS OF HOSPITAL
Dr. Winford H. Smith, director of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, in a recent report,
stated that the hospital needs
$4,000,000 to take care of its
growing number of patients.
Justifying his statement,
Dr. Smith advanced as reasons the high cost of modern
scientific surgery, drugs, and
apparatus, and the increased
expense of food service, nurse
attendance, and labor. At the
dinner of the Baltimore Association of Commerce that was
to have taken place on Wednesday, a plaque was to be
presented to the hospital. The
dinner has been postponed indefinitely, but may take place
in the future.

BROADUS MITCHELL
TO TALK THURSDAY
Will Probably Speak on Relation Of Undergraduates
To Faculty
CALLS STUDENTS RUDE
Claims He Took Course In Exiting From Drawing
Room
After numerous requests from
the undergraduate body, Francis
Warlow, president of the Student
Council, has procured the services
of Dr. Broadus Mitchell for
Thursday's Assembly.
The subject as yet has not been
ascertained, and it is believed he
will repeat his proceedure of last
year, with an impromptu speech.
His subject usually has no connection with politics or statesmanship,
but rather with the undergraduates
and their relation to the college and
the faculty.

SECOND HALF SCORING CHANCES
ARE TWICE MUFFED BY HOPKINS
Hopkins Shown To Best Advantage In Third
Session, Despite Fact That Only Score
Was Made In Fourth
A strong St. John's football
team, a rain-soaked field, and a
nemesis in the form of Armacost,
Johnnie captain, all combined to
spell defeat for the lighter Hopkins
team at Homewood field last Friday night. As a result about 4,000
fans sat through a light mist and
watched the Annapolitans down the
Jays to the tune of 26-6.
It seemed as though everything
broke wrong for the Jays that night.
Lyons slipped as he was about to
tackle Armacost when the latter
scored the initial touchdown and
intercepted passes seemed to come
at the time that they did the most
damage. Not that the Black and
Blue team had any alibi to offer or
that they wished to offer one. Nothing can erase the fact that they
failed to score in the third quarter
when thy were on the two-yard line
or that they were on the short end
the rushing as statistics show that

Game Not A Walkover

However with a fair share of the
breaks the game would have been
more of a battle although it must be
said that the game was not the
walk-over that the score would indicate.
St. John's scored in the opening
quarter when Cassassa returned
one of Lyons' punts to the Johnnies' 35-yard line. Here Armacost
took the ball and cut through the
Black and -Blue forward line. With
his two teammates acting as interferers for him he advanced toward
the goal line with only Lyons, the
safety man, in his path.
As the Jay quarterback dove for
him he slipped and Armacost covered the remaining distance with
ease. P. Lotz added the extra point
and the Orange and Black eleven
had a lead which they did not relinquish for the remainder of the

Silhouetted against a green velvet drape specially prepared for her
in Dr. French's office, stands a
serene Chinese maiden, displaying
the calm placidness so characteristic of her race. She is Kuan Yin,
goddess of mercy, one of the most
famous Chinese masterpieces of all
time.
Kuan Yin is the property of Mr.
C. M. Chen, an A. B. and A. M.
graduate student at Hopkins. He
taught in China, but after attending
a missionary conference in America
some ten years ago, decided to re-.
main in America to study, meanwhile supporting himself by the
sale of divers Chinese objets d'art.

EDII ORIALS

A

a discovery was this that they
carried the news to the emperor
immediately. Thereupon the ruler
summoned the best ivory sculptor
in the country and commissioned
him to carve a Kuan Yin statue of
the tusk of this elephant. For three
years the artist worked continuously.
The model for this figure was the
painting that was done by the greatest of all Chinese artists of the
T'ang dynasty, Wu Tao-Tze. He
was the court painter for Emperor
Ming Huang. His divine inspiration emanated from his intensive
study of the Buddhist scriptures.
This subject absorbed him so completely that he often had visions of
Buddhist figures floating in mid-air,
figures that were seen by no other
than him. He excelled in Buddhist
and Taoist figures.
Figure 24 Inches High

The entire figure and part of the
base are made of one solid piece of
ivory twenty inches high. From the
second platform, or the part on
which the lotus throne rests to the
bottom is another piece of solid
ivory; this measures four inches in
height. The figure including the
base stands twenty-four inches in
height. This is a masterpiece in
which the artist attained the greatest degree of perfection ever hoped
to be reached by anyone. The technique and design of this carving is
so well done that they characterize
a type of progress in art that has
never been paralleled. During the
ages this ivory has grown to be a
deep, rich cream. So lifelike is this
statue that it seems to be beyond
the skill of mere man.

night at the Lyric Theatre four leading minds expressed
LAST
diversified views on their respective spiritual beliefs. Those who
were present at the religious forum were undoubtedly swayed more
by the speaker who preached the doctrines which they themselves upheld. This is only natural. It stands to reason that a person will
support those things which were drilled into him since childhood by
the various organs of his sect. However, gatherings such as last night's
at which the views' of intelligent men are brought fefore the public
in an unbiased light, tend to bring the visions of the prophets nearer
to reality. And yet, certain individuals are so constituted that they
bear contempt towards anyone who holds a religious belief which
differs from their own.
It seems that the college man trends towards a general laxity as
far as actual belief in a divine being is concerned. He admits that the
various religious sects have done a great deal of good in upholding the
morals and promoting the welfare of the community. Strange to say,
the uneducated man takes the teachings of the church verbatim and
believes he sees, hears and feels his God, while the educated man
says, "I don't know." This is a factor which religious leaders are
trying to offset, and accounts in a way for the growing liberalizing
influence in religion.
The college man should have definite religious beliefs. It seems
quite ignorant to say, "I don't know." Such an answer is not sufficient.
More attention should be given to the consideraiton of the problems
and philosophy of religion. The college man should, at least, be able
to discuss them with an intelligent and unprejudiced point of view.
S. L.

RESERVE STRENGTH
three successive years the Jays have bowed to St. John's. Last
F ORFriday's
defeat was not as one-sided as those of the two previous
years. Hopkins has improved. The Jays did not get the breaks in any
way. The wet weather which hindered the Jay passing attack was advantageous to the heavy, hard-charging St. John's line. The improvement over Jay teams of the last two years was noticeable, however. A
dry day and a few breaks early in the game might have resulted in a
victory for the Homewood eleven.
The most noticeable difference in the play of the two teams was
the tackling. In this department the visitors outclassed the home
team. We believe that a word of explanation is necessary on this
point. The Hopkins team has had live tackling practice only once this
year. The coaching staff feels that it can better afford loose tackling
than take the chance of losing several valuable members of the team.
It is again the lack of reserve strength that accounts for the Jay weakness. In future years, if the amount of available material continues
to increase as it did this season, better tackling and better teams may
be expected.
St. John's pointed for this game, and played almost flawlessly
throughout the contest. The Jays never had a chance after Armacost's
65-yard run, but did not completely collapse as the teams of the two
previous years have done. They fought the Johnnies during the
second half, and deserve credit for playing a superior and more experienced eleven to a standstill during the last thirty minutes of play.
It was the lack of reserve strength that was again responsible for the
defeat of the Homewood eleven.

The Y. M. C. A.'s seven-day
campaign for funds was officially
closed last Friday at a luncheon
meeting of the team captains in
Levering Hall. The pledges of
those whos have responded to the
"Y's" call for finances amounted to
$1461.25, or approximately $225 in
excess of the goal originally set.
Mr. Schaal, executive secretary
of the "Y," received the reports of
the various team captains as to the
amounts which their groups had
collected. The only extraordinary
sum reported was that announced
by Gus Burke. He and his team,
comprising \Vilbur Bloom and
David Dolowitz, had collected $560.
Of this, $430 was attributed to
Burke's personal efforts, with the
result that he was declared indisputably the winner of the loving
cup which had been provided for
the campaigner collecting the most
money.
Edwin Lockard, master of ceremonies, congratulated Burke before presenting him with the cup.
He declared that Burke's efforts
had made those of other workers
appear somewhat diminutive. Lockard also thanked the others who
had given their services to the drive,
Mount and Gude receiving special
mention and praise.
The outstanding groups were,
first, Burke's, $560; second, Levy's,
$108; third. the Board of Managers, $97.50, and fourth, Glass'
team, $95.50.
The sum thus collected will serve
to enable the Y. M. C. A. to enact
the extensive program of activity
which it has planned for the corning year.

And Van Sant Form Nucleus

Wrestling at Hopkins has progressed rapidly since its inception
here two .weeks ago. About fifty
men have signed up for wrestling,
although but ten of these have attended practice. The team will
consist of men in the 115, 125, 135,
145, 155, 165, 175 pound classes,
and an unlimited weight class.
Thus far, there have been no candidates for the 115 and 175 pound
classes. Official practices are held
every Wednesday and Thursday at
1 P. M. and at 4 P. M. No schedule
will be arranged until funds can be
raised and the showing at practice
improves.
Dave Leury, Mike Scrofani, Mac
Murray, Bachman and Gus Van
Sant have shown great interest in
the sport, and these men probably
will make up the nucleus of the
team. Leury is a former Maryland
scholastic and South Atlantic champion in his class. He has volunteered to give his time to the instruction of those inexperienced
men who are interested in wrestling.
Bachman was a regular on the
University of Maryland team last
year, and a finalist in the South
Atlantic championships. Mac Murray and Scrofani have both had
several years of scholastic wrestling
experience, and Van Sant was a
runner-up in the amateur championships of last year. The latter
will be very valuable to the team
both as a competitor and an instructor.

Friday, November 14, it was disclosed that the next issue of the Jay
will appear sometime before the
Hopkins-Maryland gridiron tilt on
Thanksgiving Day. The issue will
be a football number, and for this
reason will probably appear as close
to the day of the game as possible.
A Christmas number will follow
the pre-game issue. Candidates, it
was learned, must submit at least
two pages of copy and one page of
exchanges on or before December 5.

At their meeting yesterday afternoon, the Interfraternity Board
failed to come to a definite decision
regarding rushing rules for the
coining year. However, it was decided that pledging would take
Place on the first or second Monday
of the second semester. If it occurs
011 the second Monday, the "Allotted Open House System" will be
;operative.
Under this plan each fraternity is
assigned one night when" it may
hold open house, on which -night it
-has priority over all others. The
Obvious benefit of such _a system is
to give the potential pledgee a
chance to attend all the open houses
he desires and orientate himself to
the best advantage.

LAYS GRAFT TO
PUBLIC APATHY

DR. W. H. SMITH CITES
NEEDS OF HOSPITAL
Dr. Winford H. Smith, director of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, in a recent report,
stated that the hospital needs
$4,000,000 to take care of its
growing number of patients.
Justifying his statement,
Dr. Smith advanced as reasons the high cost of modern
scientific surgery, drugs, and
apparatus, and the increased
expense of food service, nurse
attendance, and labor. At the
dinner of the Baltimore Association of Commerce that was
to have taken place on Wednesday, a plaque was to be
presented to the hospital. The
dinner has been postponed indefinitely, but may take place
in the future.

BROADUS MITCHELL
TO TALK THURSDAY
Will Probably Speak on Relation Of Undergraduates
To Faculty
CALLS STUDENTS RUDE
Claims He Took Course In Exiting From Drawing
Room
After numerous requests from
the undergraduate body, Francis
Warlow, president of the Student
Council, has procured the services
of Dr. Broadus Mitchell for
Thursday's Assembly.
The subject as yet has not been
ascertained, and it is believed he
will repeat his proceedure of last
year, with an impromptu speech.
His subject usually has no connection with politics or statesmanship,
but rather with the undergraduates
and their relation to the college and
the faculty.

Silhouetted against a green velvet drape specially prepared for her
in Dr. French's office, stands a
serene Chinese maiden, displaying
the calm placidness so characteristic of her race. She is Kuan Yin,
goddess of mercy, one of the most
famous Chinese masterpieces of all
time.
Kuan Yin is the property of Mr.
C. M. Chen, an A. B. and A. M.
graduate student at Hopkins. He
taught in China, but after attending
a missionary conference in America
some ten years ago, decided to re-.
main in America to study, meanwhile supporting himself by the
sale of divers Chinese objets d'art.

EDII ORIALS

a discovery was this that they
carried the news to the emperor
immediately. Thereupon the ruler
summoned the best ivory sculptor
in the country and commissioned
him to carve a Kuan Yin statue of
the tusk of this elephant. For three
years the artist worked continuously.
The model for this figure was the
painting that was done by the greatest of all Chinese artists of the
T'ang dynasty, Wu Tao-Tze. He
was the court painter for Emperor
Ming Huang. His divine inspiration emanated from his intensive
study of the Buddhist scriptures.
This subject absorbed him so completely that he often had visions of
Buddhist figures floating in mid-air,
figures that were seen by no other
than him. He excelled in Buddhist
and Taoist figures.
Figure 24 Inches High

The entire figure and part of the
base are made of one solid piece of
ivory twenty inches high. From the
second platform, or the part on
which the lotus throne rests to the
bottom is another piece of solid
ivory; this measures four inches in
height. The figure including the
base stands twenty-four inches in
height. This is a masterpiece in
which the artist attained the greatest degree of perfection ever hoped
to be reached by anyone. The technique and design of this carving is
so well done that they characterize
a type of progress in art that has
never been paralleled. During the
ages this ivory has grown to be a
deep, rich cream. So lifelike is this
statue that it seems to be beyond
the skill of mere man.

EXCEEDS SET GOAL

night at the Lyric Theatre four leading minds expressed
LAST
diversified views on their respective spiritual beliefs. Those who
were present at the religious forum were undoubtedly swayed more
by the speaker who preached the doctrines which they themselves upheld. This is only natural. It stands to reason that a person will
support those things which were drilled into him since childhood by
the various organs of his sect. However, gatherings such as last night's
at which the views' of intelligent men are brought fefore the public
in an unbiased light, tend to bring the visions of the prophets nearer
to reality. And yet, certain individuals are so constituted that they
bear contempt towards anyone who holds a religious belief which
differs from their own.
It seems that the college man trends towards a general laxity as
far as actual belief in a divine being is concerned. He admits that the
various religious sects have done a great deal of good in upholding the
morals and promoting the welfare of the community. Strange to say,
the uneducated man takes the teachings of the church verbatim and
believes he sees, hears and feels his God, while the educated man
says, "I don't know." This is a factor which religious leaders are
trying to offset, and accounts in a way for the growing liberalizing
influence in religion.
The college man should have definite religious beliefs. It seems
quite ignorant to say, "I don't know." Such an answer is not sufficient.
More attention should be given to the consideraiton of the problems
and philosophy of religion. The college man should, at least, be able
to discuss them with an intelligent and unprejudiced point of view.
S. L.

RESERVE STRENGTH
three successive years the Jays have bowed to St. John's. Last
F ORFriday's
defeat was not as one-sided as those of the two previous
years. Hopkins has improved. The Jays did not get the breaks in any
way. The wet weather which hindered the Jay passing attack was advantageous to the heavy, hard-charging St. John's line. The improvement over Jay teams of the last two years was noticeable, however. A
dry day and a few breaks early in the game might have resulted in a
victory for the Homewood eleven.
The most noticeable difference in the play of the two teams was
the tackling. In this department the visitors outclassed the home
team. We believe that a word of explanation is necessary on this
point. The Hopkins team has had live tackling practice only once this
year. The coaching staff feels that it can better afford loose tackling
than take the chance of losing several valuable members of the team.
It is again the lack of reserve strength that accounts for the Jay weakness. In future years, if the amount of available material continues
to increase as it did this season, better tackling and better teams may
be expected.
St. John's pointed for this game, and played almost flawlessly
throughout the contest. The Jays never had a chance after Armacost's
65-yard run, but did not completely collapse as the teams of the two
previous years have done. They fought the Johnnies during the
second half, and deserve credit for playing a superior and more experienced eleven to a standstill during the last thirty minutes of play.
It was the lack of reserve strength that was again responsible for the
defeat of the Homewood eleven.

The Y. M. C. A.'s seven-day
campaign for funds was officially
closed last Friday at a luncheon
meeting of the team captains in
Levering Hall. The pledges of
those whos have responded to the
"Y's" call for finances amounted to
$1461.25, or approximately $225 in
excess of the goal originally set.
Mr. Schaal, executive secretary
of the "Y," received the reports of
the various team captains as to the
amounts which their groups had
collected. The only extraordinary
sum reported was that announced
by Gus Burke. He and his team,
comprising \Vilbur Bloom and
David Dolowitz, had collected $560.
Of this, $430 was attributed to
Burke's personal efforts, with the
result that he was declared indisputably the winner of the loving
cup which had been provided for
the campaigner collecting the most
money.
Edwin Lockard, master of ceremonies, congratulated Burke before presenting him with the cup.
He declared that Burke's efforts
had made those of other workers
appear somewhat diminutive. Lockard also thanked the others who
had given their services to the drive,
Mount and Gude receiving special
mention and praise.
The outstanding groups were,
first, Burke's, $560; second, Levy's,
$108; third. the Board of Managers, $97.50, and fourth, Glass'
team, $95.50.
The sum thus collected will serve
to enable the Y. M. C. A. to enact
the extensive program of activity
which it has planned for the corning year.

And Van Sant Form Nucleus

Wrestling at Hopkins has progressed rapidly since its inception
here two .weeks ago. About fifty
men have signed up for wrestling,
although but ten of these have attended practice. The team will
consist of men in the 115, 125, 135,
145, 155, 165, 175 pound classes,
and an unlimited weight class.
Thus far, there have been no candidates for the 115 and 175 pound
classes. Official practices are held
every Wednesday and Thursday at
1 P. M. and at 4 P. M. No schedule
will be arranged until funds can be
raised and the showing at practice
improves.
Dave Leury, Mike Scrofani, Mac
Murray, Bachman and Gus Van
Sant have shown great interest in
the sport, and these men probably
will make up the nucleus of the
team. Leury is a former Maryland
scholastic and South Atlantic champion in his class. He has volunteered to give his time to the instruction of those inexperienced
men who are interested in wrestling.
Bachman was a regular on the
University of Maryland team last
year, and a finalist in the South
Atlantic championships. Mac Murray and Scrofani have both had
several years of scholastic wrestling
experience, and Van Sant was a
runner-up in the amateur championships of last year. The latter
will be very valuable to the team
both as a competitor and an instructor.

Friday, November 14, it was disclosed that the next issue of the Jay
will appear sometime before the
Hopkins-Maryland gridiron tilt on
Thanksgiving Day. The issue will
be a football number, and for this
reason will probably appear as close
to the day of the game as possible.
A Christmas number will follow
the pre-game issue. Candidates, it
was learned, must submit at least
two pages of copy and one page of
exchanges on or before December 5.

would influence the selection of
staff candidates would be introduced. Subscription books were
distributed among the candidates;
these subscriptions are valued at $1

Hullabaloo Pictures

Maurice Miller, business manager of the 1931 Hullabaloo, states
that today and tomorrow offer the
last opportunities for Senior class
members to have individual pictures taken for the annual.
On Thursday at 12:20 in the
Hullabaloo office, Levering Hall,
the candidates for the business staff
will meet to organize for work on
this edition of the year book. Miller
requests that candidates for the
staff be present.
Townsend Parks, editor-in-chief,
reports that the editorial staff has
complete plans in view and that it
is only a matter of time until a
definite course of action will be inaugurated.
